stream_context.summary: Kaze concentrates on importing Biobak’s new assets (Poochie area, gates, rotating apple, flower Shy Guy) while refining engine systems—especially collision reliability and memory use—inside a late-game basement/temple section featuring Poochie, a giant chasing egg and puzzle doors.

development_findings.summary: Implemented rubber-band logic so the giant egg accelerates if the player gets ahead, keeping the chase exciting.
Added stage lights to the big egg to match Biobak’s concept art.
Overworld had a missing segment; Kaze restored it and will resume overworld work after this level is finished.
Created a new collision routine that removes quarter-frame randomness; Mario now always sticks to walkable slopes, giving fully predictable movement.
development_findings.quote: I feel like there never should be any randomness in Mario's movement.

development_findings.summary: Identified landing sub-frame inconsistency; considering further fixes but full delta-time physics would be too invasive.
Recent engine upgrades caused legacy assets to break; most upgrades are now complete so instability should subside.
Hit N64 8 MB RAM limit; moved small actor data to an emergency pool and plans to delete unused Mario 64 assets to stay under 64 MB ROM cap (currently ~60 MB).
development_findings.quote: We really are approaching the 64 megabytes.

development_findings.summary: Wrote CPU code that calculates per-vertex shading at runtime for the rotating apple so it retains vertex colours yet looks lit while spinning.
development_findings.quote: All this just to get some shadows on the stupid apple.

development_findings.summary: Imported Biobak’s updated Poochie (fewer materials, new colours); model functions in-game but feet mirroring and minor rig issues remain.
Fixed temple gate transparency by converting to proper decal ordering, resolved door opening logic and improved culling radius for performance.
Save blocks broke during engine changes; flagged for later repair.
Exploring split-screen multiplayer (two stacked viewports) which would cut frame-buffers but increase memory needs.

context_findings.summary: Philosophy: randomness in core movement is unacceptable; mechanics must be consistent so players never think about frame precision.
context_findings.quote: I feel like there never should be any randomness in Mario's movement.

context_findings.summary: Tool stance: master hotkeys first, then ‘have fun’—efficiency over exploration in Blender.
context_findings.quote: Learn your tools at first and then you get to have fun.

context_findings.summary: Proud of collision breakthrough; frustrated by Windows 11 UI quirks and memory bugs.
Personal snippets: joking that wife shaved his hair; baby now babbles ‘baa baa’; excited to reunite with repaired robotic lawn-mower ‘pet’.
Merch store integration with YouTube delayed; mild annoyance voiced.
On vacation; next stream Monday; off-stream time used mainly for bug-fixing.

biobak.summary: Supplied numerous assets: egg stage lights, temple gates, redesigned Poochie, updated shy guys, rotating apple; optimised materials and vertex counts to save RAM.
Provided a new F3 (Fangame Fest) thumbnail that Kaze likes; ongoing visual branding assistance.

zeina.summary: Originally created older shy guy models/animations; new versions need updated rigs. Sent a fresh F3 thumbnail asset (per Kaze’s ‘she’ reference).

key_stories.title: Smoothing Out Mario’s Quarter-Frame Chaos
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovered slope behavior was effectively random in vanilla SM64 due to quarter-frame precision. He rewrote collision to make slope interactions deterministic.
key_stories.challenge: Player could either stick or fly off slopes unpredictably.
key_stories.process: Built a ‘nearly continuous’ collision routine that ignores quarter-frames.
key_stories.outcome: Movement is now predictable and player-friendly.
key_stories.key_quote: I feel like there never should be any randomness in Mario's movement.

key_stories.title: The Memory Crunch
key_stories.summary: New assets drove the project over the 8 MB RAM ceiling and near the 64 MB ROM limit.
key_stories.process: Shifted small data into the emergency pool and planned code/asset trimming.
key_stories.outcome: Level loads again; temporary head-room secured.
key_stories.key_quote: We really are approaching the 64 megabytes.

key_stories.title: Rotating Apple Lighting Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Static vertex-coloured apple looked flat while spinning.
key_stories.challenge: Needed shading without losing vertex colours.
key_stories.process: Calculated per-vertex light levels on CPU each frame, using object-space normals.
key_stories.outcome: Apple now appears properly lit and vibrant.
key_stories.key_quote: All this just to get some shadows on the stupid apple.
